content.title: UK union loses latest bid to push for workers' rights at Deliveroo - Reuters UK
content.desc: The High Court has rejected the latest attempt by a British trade union to push for workers' rights at food courier Deliveroo, in a case which is a rare example of gig economy firms successfully defending their business models. The Independent Workers Union of Great Britain (IWGB) wants to represent riders in the north London area of Camden, hoping to secure rights such as the minimum wage, which they are not currently entitled to, due to being classified as self-employed. content.title: Deliveroo riders not entitled to collective bargaining - Financial Times
content.desc: Deliveroo riders are not entitled to collective bargaining the High Court ruled on Wednesday in the latest legal case for the “gig” economy. The High Court dismissed a judicial review challenge brought by the Independent Workers Union of Great Britain, a trade union, which argued that it should be recognised by the food delivery company for the purposes of collective bargaining for its riders. The union claimed that not allowing collective bargaining breached the human rights of Deliveroo riders, under Article 11 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
